The ink particles contain heavy metals, and that doesn't change when the ink particles are broken down during the laser treatment.  Then, the white blood cells remove ink particles, taking them from the dermal layers through the lymph to the liver.  Some heavy metals are notoriously difficult to remove from the body, so exposing the liver to the heavy metals found in the ink particles doesn't sound like good thing me.

The thing about tattoos is that they're not for everyone and everyone's reason for getting one is different. Some people get them as a memorial for a lost loved one, some people get certain ones because they have a deep meaning to them, and others (like myself) get them because we love art in all of its forms and want to be a canvas for the art to be seen. I have a tattoo of a skull with a dead tree growing through it and I get asked a lot what the meaning behind it is and to be totally honest, I can't answer that question very simply due to the fact that it's just one piece of a larger picture that will be part of my sleeve and entire tattoo scheme. I chose that particular picture because I just loved the imagery of it, but it fits the scheme of life and death that I'm going for with my tattoos. If you're going to get a tattoo, first make sure that you REALLY want it so you don't just throw your money down the drain and get it removed, also go to a certified professional and not some rundown janky ink parlor or just a friend that watched a youtube video once.

Great Video, yet a couple of technical issues that are not quite right. The frosting caused by the laser usually lasts up to 20 minutes after the treatment. The frosting is actually nitrogen bubbles created in the skin when the ink fragmentation takes place. Also if you use a Q switch laser for the tattoo removal (the vast majority are Q switch) then no heat is created, the laser actually fragments the particles with shock wavers. IPL which is not recommended for laser tattoo removal due to scar risks is the systems that heats the ink as is not as affective as Q switch. Other than that all the other explanations are spot on. Also it should be noted that only Blacks, blues, Reds and green pigments can be removed by laser so be careful when choosing your tattoo colours.

1 million viewers didn't get smarter this day, because Destin told urban legends about tattoo ink pigments. That's disappointing, considering he had bottles in front of him, with ingredients written on them! There is no cadmium or cobalt in tattoo ink! He probably commited the crime of trusting Wikipedia. I'd suggest a more reliable source, for example, tattoo ink manufacturer (Intenze) MSDS. Here we go:

1. Blue and green comes from copper organic complexes - phthalocyanines, like pigment blue 15 (C.i. 74160), green 7 (c.i. 74260);
2. Red, orange and yellow are usually azo pigments, for example C.I.11767, C.i. 12475;
3. Dioxazine purple is purple;
4. Quinacridone magenta is magenta;
5. Inorganic pigments used for tattoo ink are white titanium dioxide, and carbon black.

Some manufacturers use diketo-pyrrolo-pyrrole red and iron oxides for brown. Chlorinated copper phthalocyanine is banned in Europe, so chlorobrominated is used (Green #36). But in general, there are no cadmium, lead or mercury compounds in tattoo ink. A tattooist is not a reliable source, either. He may be an outstanding artist, but is very unlikely to know what his ink is made of.

Immune is all about leukocyte (the white blood). If you wanna know the comparison between the metal substance (which is in tattoo ink) and the blood size (here, it should be the white blood or leukocyte), you're wrong if you think the round cell is the leukocyte, that's erythrocyte. And erythrocytes function is to carry oxygen, not related at all to immunity.

Did you know there is a tattoo pigment that was designed by some folks at Harvard to be removed in one laser treatment?  I don't know exactly what is in it but the basics work like this:  The pigments used to create the coloration aren't actually able to remain under your skin on their own; instead they bond with polymers that can.  This means that when you get a single laser removal treatment, the polymer is totally destroyed by the laser that was originally intended to tackle heavy metals.  In the following few weeks your body has no problem removing the pigments no longer bonded to the much larger polymers!  Pretty cool huh!
